comments.commentBody: eddy: Yes. The radioactivity   released in Japan has received little mention for the  Green / Environmental  Contingent .  Very surprising.

As always humans assume that as they progressively destroy their own life support systems one-by-one they will remain untouched by any results.  If I were a betting man, I wouldn't give a nickel if asked to bet if human civilization will exist in 300 years.  It's sad.  It is possible to maintain our 'home' but instead humans treat this family homestead as if it were a garbage dump instead of a home.

Yeah. Darn fire-yelling scientists. So dour.

Oh well, what are you going to do.

Anyway, I'm sure modern science will come up with some solution to this mess.
I hope so, and the sooner the better. We have proved our species to be a destructive dead end annomally . Begone I say and let the Earth survive.
...but the ocean may become a desert.
10 billion cavemen cannot produce enough damage to seriously alter the Earth systems, or even speed up the alteration. You're close, but not close enough.

Humans have been grouping up as clans and tribes since they figured out they were safer and more secure. Actually a pretty good plan and thinking.

Never before have tribes had the technology to totally destroy not only their enemies but the very things that actually keep them alive themselves. We could actually destroy all civilization since the first clan in a day now. Maybe even all life of any species for another geologic time frame. That will happen eventually in how many billion years? Why should we now end up making it happen so much sooner?
Yes, I am heartbroken...I have seen a great bumper sticker around: "We are not the only species, we just act like we are."

and let's not forget the bees.
No bees..... no pollination..... no food.

We have been given a paradise, not unlike the biblical garden that Adam and Eve enjoyed, but many don't seem to see it's profound beauty. Rain forests are torched in the Amazon, Indonesia, and Alberta Canada. Garbage is produced at a rate of 4 pounds per person per day. That's 28 billion pounds of trash PER DAY, much of it some form of plastic.  Marine life is choking on plastic. Pesticides are sprayed everywhere, including on your neighbors's lawn. And pesticides are found to pollute every stream and over 90% of wells sampled in a study by the US Geological Survey.  Surely if man could recognize beauty, he would be outraged that deforestation and pesticide addiction has nearly driven one of the most magically transcendent creatures on Earth to extinction: namely the migratory monarch butterfly. He would be outraged, if he had a soul.

Actually, I was kind of pulling for Guardians of the Galaxy. I guess this proves the Oscars will not recognize great performances by people with green or grey skin. Not to mention the total lack of consideration for racoons and plant based life forms in supporting roles.

Think carefully about what you've said: The fellow you speak of made a commitment to this woman for time and eternity. Perhaps, and I'm assuming here, he even looked her in the eye and told her he loved her and only her. He, and I'm assuming again, was able to have sexual relations with her on at least three different occasions. Then, one day, he cannot continue the "facade" any longer. He proclaims his gayness and leaves her (and I'm guessing here) for another man.

And then you write to the New York Times and blame the LDS faith and it's leaders for this poor, woeful soul.
What he wasn't behind was the war.

This is really a non-issue. I'm also surprised that no one has mentioned that the film got LBJ totally wrong; in this aspect of the lionization of MLK, Lyndon Johnson was actually totally and completely behind the Voting Rights Bill. Zero Dark Thirty last year played loose and fast factually and I thought that might have hurt it's chances.

Not a bad final five considering that two of the very best contenders- Turkey's Winter Sleep and Belgium's Two Days One Night- were eliminated in the first round. Then again, Ida should have been a Best Picture contender.

Boeingflyer:

In 1961, as a high school kid from England, I clearly remember a train trip from NYC to New Orleans where my parents were posted. At one point, the train passed two tumbledown tar paper shacks. They were latrines. One was marked "Colored" and the other "White." Separate but equal!

Of course, even back in England, at HS and later college, like everyone of my generation, I cheered Martin Luther King on and followed the American civil rights revolution with passionate interest.

If anyone chronicles those events without trying to get every historical detail exactly right then I think they are betraying their profession. The truth is far too important to take liberties with.

I agree that the movie does have documentary value - even with its inaccurate depiction of President Johnson - and King for that matter.
But the fact remains. As a movie - it was not well done. Not terribly bad - just not very good.

I was a child in a liberal, Jewish family near Chicago when, in 1961, in 7th grade, I went on a school trip to Washington, DC. I remember my 13 year old outrage when I saw "Colored" and "White" toilets and drinking fountains in Virginia, a short drive from our nations capital.
Selma was a pivotal and heroic event in a shameful chapter of our history. Other than failing to give LBJ full credit for his leading role along with MLK, this is a must see movie for the many who have no idea of how bad it was. I have a 26 year old daughter who views this event as history, which for her it is. She will see this movie and have her world changed. As WW2 vets said when asked about the authenticity of the movie Saving Private Ryan: "Yeah, it was just like that, but 10 times worse."
I, do not agree that in this commercially driven industry that this movie or its tremendous significance is diminished by the nominations and voting of the academy, who has, by the way, supported and contributed creatively to expanding our awareness and understanding of ourselves and how we've behaved. As others have commented, recognition last year of Twelve Years A Slave certainly establishes some strong credibility for Hollywoods ability to recognize and reward some very unpleasant periods in our past and people of color.

In addition.......that 1.5 Trillion dollars saved with cheaper oil equates to about 2 percent of world GDP. That extra money in consumers pockets could be spent generating new jobs and manufacturing further escalating economic growth. The last I heard, our economy was growing at about a 3 percent annual rate. I wonder what it would be if that oil savings were spent?

That simple 2 percent spent could be a real catalyst. People should spend the excess money they save on energy efficiency efforts to further reduce oil demand. Seal the living space of your home or apartment to save both heated and cooled air and add more insulation to the attic, floors, and ductwork. Buy a new fuel efficient car. These expenditures will reinforce manufacturing and further reduce our oil use keeping prices low.

Film is powerful on so many levels.  The Oscars will likely be a poor barometer of social impact of a film or the actresses/actors because the award itself is about art more than it is about social bearings .  As far as the acting goes this movie was exceptional in my opinion. David Oyelowo's performance takes all of us into the very personal, painful and uncertain realities of taking on great causes and all of the personal risk that goes along with it.  When he reaches out to Mahalia Jackson, we all are reminded that the great women and men almost never walk alone.  Awards may have missed this one but my sense is that Ava DuVernay likely didn't build this story around award nominations but around the profound power of the human spirit when it is stirred by a great leader across a people of great courage.

Dieudonne EMPATHIZED with Ahmedi Coulibaly... he didn't sympathize as so many have claimed.  Nowhere in his statements did he say that he supported Coulibaly's coward criminality... he likened himself to the gunman in the limited aspect that they both, for separate, short periods of time, were "public enemy number 1" in France.  For this he was arrested.  All hail the French, convenient champions of free speech.
Martin, If you think it's tough to think like John, it's even tougher to think like Martin.

You said it, "the devastating effects of collapsed demand".  That was what we had at the end of the Bush Administration.  Spending collapsed, state government revenue disappeared, government workers were getting laid off, private industry saw the writing on the wall, decreased demand, and started laying off workers and so began the spiral to the Great Recession.  The first stimulus package was just enough to let Bush get out of town (Washington, DC) without being tarred and feathered.  The second stimulus at the beginning of the President Obama's term was another lifeline.  Has it been enough?

Second day of commenting here--and second day in a row doing a puzzle in which I got stuck on a particular concept in a way that really held me up. This time, I wanted something-RARELY for "how many practice religion" (I'm Catholic, after all). And, for earliest figures, I kept thinking "cuneiform" or something like that. I also tried to think In terms of sculpture for that one. In the future, when it comes to puzzle solving, I guess I need to have "Occam's Razor" taped to my screen. Or tattooed on my forehead.

...On the other hand, I kept taking the "blood problem, maybe" too literally. Flus? Or some genetic disease? No help from Occam's razor there.

Gah! Stupid "maybe." :)

I agree with Mr. Rao.  In one reply to Mr. Roa, someone criticized Perry for being cruel to the poor.  Perry grew up poor, but he worked his way out of poverty; he pulled himself up by his boot straps as they say.  He is the epitome of the American rags to riches story.  The self-made man.  A military hero.  Perry is an inspiration to all Americans.

Perhaps it your bias that has led you to the conclusion that "Democrats are rarely accountable for anything negative in these pages." Here are NYT articles about the topics you cite that provide clear evidence contrary to your claim:

Statistics Challenge Cuomo's Claim of Record Job Growth, March 12, 2013 (This article in part covers the upstate unemployment problems.)

Chicago Police Say Homicides Fall to Lowest Level Since 1963, August 01, 2014. (In this case, I suspect your bias did not allow for the possibility of this particular headline.

As for Governor Cuomo's "record with the Feds housing sub prime loan disaster," I am not quite sure what you are getting at there. Andrew Cuomo was not governor when the financial crisis that was triggered in part by securitization of subprime loans began. But the NY Times did have this somewhat negative story about Cuomo when he was attorney general: In Financial Crisis, No Prosecutions of Top Figures, April 14, 2011.

Did I change your mind about the NY Times lack of negative coverage of Governor Cuomo? Probably not. We all have a tendency to look past things that do not support the world view we have committed to. It is hard to change one's mind even when presented with facts that are completely contradictory to what we think.

As a TX resident for over 12 years, having migrated to the state from extremely high-tax VA, I largely have good things to say about Gov. Perry. I know I run the risk of alienating the average reader of the NY Times but my comments are based on experience working and living here.

To govern is to choose. When the fast growing Dallas metroplex needed additional highways, Gov. Perry didn't raise taxes to fund them. He entered into a public private partnership in which toll collections for the next 25 years or so go to a Spanish company in return for the company to build and maintain the new infrastructure. So, yes, we too pay tolls to drive around fast super highways - but unlike New York or elsewhere, these tolls are used expressly for what they are intended for and don't fund the city's general budget, for example.

I'm sure there have been failures in some areas as the article states but overall, Mr. Perry will be missed. And now, I will sit back and watch getting pummeled by my fellow readers.
In his farewell address I hope he doesn't try to list his top three accomplishments.

The critics in this article have hit upon most of the real issues which make Mr Perry a non-candidate for the highest office in the land. Texas seems to be a "land unto itself", executions in that state lead the country and the educational system is poor. It seems that Texas is a more or less an "enclave" in the remaining states. Of course, if the GOP nominates him as their candidate, there will be rejoicing in all Democratic states and in Washington(Democrats, of course). They can wish, but it would be a miracle if Mr Perry managed to become the GOP choice. All should remember Mr Perry as telling the nation that hospitals in Texas could control Ebola and all was well.

no way should Rick leave center stage - the comedy relief that we have all enjoyed for the last decade would be utterly irreplaceable.  Please Rick - for the sake of our psyche, run again for president - we really need the laughs you provide.
Rick Perry, the Ron Burgandy of politics.
No, no -- please run, Mr. Perry.  We need the comedy.
Compared to Gov. Perry former president George W. Bush is a rocket scientist. Let's hope the former governor removes himself from politics, for the good of his home state and the country.

Though I agree with most of what you say about Wash. U. being Coddle U., but here is the sad part.

When I taught there, there were plenty of students who wanted to learn and were willing to work hard to do so. Apparently, they weren't part of the school's "business" model. As the Math Chair shouted at me when I told him I was teaching based on my engineering background,

"I don't care!"

He told me to make the course a "cookbook" course, telling me to show the students step-by-step how to do the problems that would be on the test. Had I done that, those serious students would have been robbed of the education that they deserved - and got. All the students learned well.

But no one should think that Wash. U.'s behavior stands out that much.

There is a reason why, across the country, students are only required to study about 13 hours a week to get a better grade than students from the 60's got by studying 25 hours a week. The difference in critical thinking after two years of college is now almost zero. It used to be one sigma.

David Riesman saw the reason 35 years ago, when he wrote his "On Higher Education: The Academic Enterprise in an Era of Rising Student Consumerism". Here is what he wrote.

“…advantage can still be taken of [students] by unscrupulous instructors and institutions...like any other interest group, the student estate often does not grasp its own interests, and those who speak in its name are not always its friends.”

I went to Wash U in the mid 90' and witnessed the very thing you're speaking of.

(My experience with Student Financial Aid, though, was exceptional. I was accepted soely on merit, and only then submitted my family's financial information. I was awarded $17,000 per year in need-based grant, that is, they slashed that much off each year's tuition fees)

But even then it seemed that consumerism has so infested academia, that colleges were more concerned about making school 'a nice experience' than they were about maintaining high standards. And hell-bent on making certain everyone got 'their money's worth.'

With the general decline in education standards everywhere, I think the common attitude is: "Who cares about an undergraduate degree anyway? Any serious student, intending to progress in this field, will go on to graduate school.'

Undergraduate degrees are no longer a guarantee of anything, not even a minimum standard of competence in one's chosen area of study.

this is the university's response to the federal government's pressure to have rising graduation rates within four years. if students don't graduate in that span of time, it is not the student's fault, but rather the fault of the institution and since graduation and retention rates are big factors in rankings and can be potentially tied to government withdrawal of aide, the universities have enormous pressure to graduate students who should not graduate.

i had premed classes where the professor was on academic probation for failing too many students. this is unlikely to happen in our new environment. everyone will get a gentlemen's "B" and everyone will graduate on time with great GPAs. The average grade at Stanford is a "B+". This may make sense (not really) at Stanford, where the average student is expected to be exceptional. But the immense pressures of graduation and retention rates will mean that most students who just show up will pass in community colleges and state schools. we will be heading into an age of rubber stamping college graduates who are not much better off in terms of analytic skills and thinking than when they graduated from high school.

Wash U has been labeled Coddle University for some time. That fact must be known by the administration of Wash U. Top students express disdain for the use of luxury to attract students with money and the very students that Wash U is trying to attract are turned off by it. That is, top students from wealthy households speak of Wash U in critical tones because the perception is that they are trying to attract students via coddling, absurd luxuries and deference to privilege. Even their decision to expand aid reeks of something different than (and less than) a true commitment to  finding ways to help educate capable students not able to pay exorbitant tuition. And, tuition would not be exorbitant if not for the luxuries they have built into their climate in an attempt to attract wealthy students. The very top students, even the wealthy ones, see exactly where Wash U's  money has been spent and they tend to choose against attending. They see the lack of need blind admissions, the huge preference given to legacies and they decide to attend universities with better values.  So Wash U gets a lot of those students swayed by a posh and coddling academic climate. Is that not working for them any more?
